dt: {bc}something (such as borders or walls) that encloses

dt.t: outside the {wi}confines{/wi} of the office or hospital
escape from the {wi}confines{/wi} of soot and clutter
work within the {wi}confines{/wi} of a small group

et: Middle English {it}confynyes,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}confīnia,{/it} plural of {it}confīnium{/it} "common boundary, limit, border," from {it}confīnis{/it} "having a common boundary" (from {it}con-{/it} {et_link|con-|com-} + {it}-fīnis,{/it} adjective derivative of {it}fīnis{/it} "boundary, limit, ending") + {it}-ium,{/it} suffix of compounded nouns {ma}{mat|final:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: something (such as borders or walls) that encloses; also : something that restrains

dt.t: will {wi}confine{/wi} my remarks to one subject

pt: {sc}limit{/sc} {sc}restrict{/sc} {sc}circumscribe{/sc} {sc}confine{/sc} mean to set bounds for. {sc}limit{/sc} implies setting a point or line (as in time, space, speed, or degree) beyond which something cannot or is not permitted to go.
{sc}restrict{/sc} suggests a narrowing or tightening or restraining within or as if within an encircling boundary.

pt.t: laws intended to {it}restrict{/it} the freedom of the press

pt: {sc}circumscribe{/sc} stresses a restriction on all sides and by clearly defined boundaries.

pt.t: the work of the investigating committee was carefully {it}circumscribed{/it}

pt: {sc}confine{/sc} suggests severe restraint and a resulting cramping, fettering, or hampering.

et: borrowed from Middle French {it}confiner{/it} "to be adjacent, restrain within limits," probably borrowed from Italian {it}confinare,{/it} derivative of {it}confine{/it} "boundary line, limit," noun derivative from neuter of Latin {it}confīnis{/it} "having a common boundary" {ma}{mat|confine:1|}{/ma}
